thread.title: Ben Bradshaw asks whether it is possible to halt Brexit

author: Daniel Clark
title: Ben Bradshaw asks whether it is possible to halt Brexit
text:
Ben Bradshaw asks whether it is possible to halt Brexit The Labour MP raised the question during a debate in the House of Commons Share   Comments 
Exeter MP Ben Bradshaw asked in Parliament whether it was possible, if necessary, to halt the process of the UK leaving to European Union. 
The Labour MP, who has come up strongly against Brexit, raised the question during a debate in the House of Commons on Monday about the UKs Plans for Leaving the EU 
Ben Bradshaw asked: “Is it the Prime Minister's understanding that, if necessary, it is possible to halt the article 50 process?” Ben Bradshaw 
In response, the Prime Minister, Theresa May, said: “The position was made clear in a case that went through the Supreme Court in relation to article 50. The Government have made it clear that we have no intention of revoking that. We will be delivering on the vote of the British people.” Read More South West Tory MEP has whip withdrawn after voting to block Brexit progress 
In the same debate, Hugo Swire, the Conservative MP for East Devon, asked: “Following the recent German elections, power has moved from Berlin to Paris, so will the Prime Minister remind President Macron of the importance of being a good neighbour to the United Kingdom, because post Brexit, France will still be our neighbour, tens of thousands of French people will still want to visit and study here, and vice versa; we will still want to co-operate on environmental issues and immigration; and we will still wish to preserve our special defence arrangements with the French?” Hugo Swire, MP for East Devon 
Mrs May replied: “My right hon. Friend makes an important point about not only our future relationship with the EU, but our future bilateral relationship with France. Read More 
“I can assure him that all the discussions that I have with President Macron, and that other Ministers have with their opposite numbers, are based on our not only maintaining but enhancing that bilateral relationship.” Like us on Facebook
